claim.text: Open community-driven platforms like Chatbot Arena collect user preference data from site visitors and have gained a reputation as one of the most trustworthy publicly available benchmarks for LLM performance.
claim.exact_quote: Open community-driven platforms like Chatbot Arena that collect user preference data from site visitors have gained a reputation as one of the most trustworthy publicly available benchmarks for LLM performance.

evidence.evidence_text: Chatbot Arena has collected 2,011,939 pairwise preference judgments as of October 6, 2024.
evidence.exact_quote: As of October 6, 2024, Chatbot Arena has collected 2,011,939 pairwise preference judgments.

evaluation.justification: The claim is supported by concrete data on the number of pairwise preference judgments collected by Chatbot Arena.

claim.text: Three sources of bad annotations, both malicious and otherwise, can corrupt the reliability of open leaderboard rankings.
claim.exact_quote: In this paper, we demonstrate that three sources of bad annotations, both malicious and otherwise, can corrupt the reliability of open leaderboard rankings.

evidence.evidence_text: The paper discusses three sources of poor-quality votes: apathetic, adversarial, and arbitrary.
evidence.exact_quote: In this paper, we demonstrate that three sources of bad annotations, both malicious and otherwise, can corrupt the reliability of open leaderboard rankings.

evaluation.justification: The claim is supported by the discussion of three specific sources of poor-quality votes.

claim.text: Only 10% of poor quality votes by apathetic or adversarial annotators can change the rankings of models by up to 5 places on the leaderboard.
claim.exact_quote: In particular, we show that only 10% of poor quality votes by apathetic or adversarial annotators can change the rankings of models by up to 5 places on the leaderboard.

evidence.evidence_text: Table 1 shows that 10% of apathetic votes can change the leaderboard rankings of 2/3 models by 5 places.
evidence.exact_quote: Table 1 summarizes our results. We find that only 10% of apathetic votes in the dataset can change the leaderboard rankings of 2/3 models by 5 places.

evaluation.justification: The claim is supported by experimental results showing the impact of apathetic votes on model rankings.

claim.text: The main attraction of open community platforms for end users is that they expose a free and easy-to-use API endpoint for LLMs.
claim.exact_quote: The main attraction of open community platforms for end users is that they expose a free and easy-to-use API endpoint for LLMs.

evidence.evidence_text: The paper discusses the incentives for users to interact with the platform and submit queries.
evidence.limitations: The claim is based on general observations and does not provide specific data.
evidence.exact_quote: The main attraction of open community platforms for end users is that they expose a free and easy-to-use API endpoint for LLMs.

evaluation.justification: The claim is supported by the discussion of user incentives to interact with the platform.
evaluation.key_limitations: The claim is based on general observations and does not provide specific data.

claim.text: Adversarial voting can change leaderboard rankings if adversaries get to contribute 10% votes for their model.
claim.exact_quote: Table 2 summarizes our results. Across all models, we show that adversarial attacks can substantially change leaderboard rankings if adversaries get to contribute 10% votes for their model.

evidence.evidence_text: Table 2 shows that adversarial attacks can change leaderboard rankings if adversaries get to contribute 10% votes for their model.
evidence.exact_quote: Table 2 summarizes our results. Across all models, we show that adversarial attacks can substantially change leaderboard rankings if adversaries get to contribute 10% votes for their model.

evaluation.justification: The claim is supported by experimental results showing the impact of adversarial votes on model rankings.

claim.text: Arbitrary votes are not 'noise' and provide useful signals about models' relative performance.
claim.exact_quote: We argue that arbitrary votes are not 'noise' and provide useful signals about models' relative performance.

evidence.evidence_text: The paper discusses the usefulness of arbitrary votes in providing signals about models' relative performance.
evidence.limitations: The claim is based on general observations and does not provide specific data.
evidence.exact_quote: We argue that arbitrary votes are not 'noise' and provide useful signals about models' relative performance.

evaluation.justification: The claim is supported by the discussion of the usefulness of arbitrary votes.
evaluation.key_limitations: The claim is based on general observations and does not provide specific data.
